Tomorrow the Hopkins stickmen will line up against one of
their most formidable opponents
of the season, the Syracuse University twelve. So far this sea
son neither Hopkins nor Syracusc
has been defeated, Hopkins having won four games, and Syracuse
two. Two weeks 'ago Syracuse
opened their season,- by defeating
the Crescent Club of New York.
This, in itself, shows that the
Orange stickmen have real class,
for any club that can beat the
Crescents must show form well
above the average.
Last year the game between
Hopkins and Syracuse resulted in
a 4-4 tie. Darkness stopped the
game before enough extra periods
could be played to finally decide
the contest. Both teams this year
have largely the same lineup as
last, so the undecided game will
be fought out tomorrow.
In the game last Saturday the
Hopkins twelve showed up to a
disadvantage, due largely to overconfidence and to poor condition.
The Syracuse team, by beating
the Crescents, showed real ability
and demonstrated that the Hopkins twelve has no reason whatsoever to be overconfident.

NINE MEETS GETTYSEURG
TOMORROW

The ball team will meet Gettysburg College tomorrow at Homewood at 2 o'clock. At the present
zime little is known of the
3trength of the visitors, although
_hey have always been known to
urn out very strong teams.
The Black and Blue team has
:3een rather successful this year,
having broken even in six games,
riot counting, of course, the Ori)le romp. The height of form, so
far, was shown in the Pittsburgh
game, when "Bobby" Owings
pitched Hopkins to a 4-2 victory.
It is expected that "Ben"
Thomas, who sprained his ankle
in a practice game a week ago,
will be in condition to return to
his old position at short for tomorrow's game."Ben," who, until
this year was an outfielder, has
been playing a steady game at the

shortfield position, and can be depended upon to come through in
the pinch, both in the field and
at the bat.
It is not definitely known who
will receive the pitching assignment tomorrow, although the
:hoice will probably rest between
Clayton and Tucker.

SCABBARD AND BLADE TO DINE

A dinner will be given by the
Scabbard and Blade Military Society at the Hopkins Club on
Monday, May 1, at 5.45 P. M.The
inspecting officers will be the
guests of honor. The meeting will
be short, so that those who wish
can attend the Cotillion afterward.

MARYLAND CASUALTY SCENE OF
NEXT COTILLION

For the first time since cotillions
have been in vogue at Hopkins one
will be held off the campus. The
last one of the year will be given
by the Cotillion Board in the Maryland Casualty Club House on May
1. According. to all reports, this
cotillion will be the biggest and gayest affair of its kind ever given by
the Cotillion Board. The Club
House is admirably suited for
such an occasion and with Lou
Fisher and his orchestra furnishing the music the affair is sure to
be a huge success. Supper will be
served between the ninth and tenth
dances by Herring, who is making
preparations for at least three hundred.

AS TO CRITICS, WISE OR OTHERWISE
Like all other home products, the News-Letter comes in for its.
share of knocks. We are glad to say, however, that ninety-five per
cent, of the criticism received comes from that class who talk a
great deal and function rarely.
The most common criticism of our sheet has been the objection to the large proportion of advertising matter. Comparison with
our exchanges, however, reveals the fact that there are fewer than
five, among the hundred or more college sheets, which have less
advertising space than our paper. In some instances the ad matter
covers two entire pages, leaving one page for notices and the front
of the sheet for news. The ad is, of course, the heart's blood of the
publication, as the news is the meat. Without the advertiser the
paper could not exist.
We realize that criticism of the work of the editorial staff is at
times justified. But we would like to call to the attention of our
critics the fact that the half-dozen men who spend from eight to
twelve hours per week at work upon the paper are not experts and
are only human; and, furthermore, that anyone of them will retire
in favor of a better man. Remember,"It is easier to be critical than
to be correct."

A REAL OPPORTUNITY
Hopkins, in the\ spring time, has opportunities that many a large
university buried in some small town would pay a large sum to own.
The wonderful athletic facilities at Homewood attract hundreds of
athletes from Baltimore prep. schools. Upon the impression that
these athletes carry back to their institutions depends, to a large
extent, the future of Hopkins.
The City of Baltimore, with its six or eight thousand male
high school students, offers as excellent a field for selection of university material as any college could desire. The director of athletics
at this University has stated that with the material turned out at the
two leading local prep. schools at his disposal, he could develop
'athletic teams to compete with any in the country.
The students who crowd our tennis courts, track and baseball,
and lacrosse fields can learn little from the University officially as to
what we have here to attract students seeking higher education. The
attractive buildings and wonderful athletic facilities speak for themselves, but it remains for the Hopkins man to show these guests that
there is as real a spirit here at Hopkins as exists at any wide-awake
institution.
As our guests, and as prospective students, it is our duty to make
the youngsters feel at home. If we could but develop a keener feeling of friendship between them and ourselves it would not be long
_before this university became the goal of every high school student
in Baltimore.
As it is, we draw a maximum number from this city. Only by
creating a demand for our "goods", however, will we be able to
pick the cream from the number of applicants.

in newspaper work, as
. like as not later on you will turn to
manufacturing or advertising or law.
You don't know where opportunity or inclination will
lead you. This fact has a great deal to do with your work
at college—not so much the things you learn as the way
you learn them.
Don't think of education as a memory test in names and
dates and definitions. That knowledge is important, but
only as an incidental. Of far greater value is the habit of
getting at underlying laws,the basic principles which tie facts
together.
The work of the pioneers in electrical experiment, at
first glance confusing, is simplified once you realize that
much of it hinged upon a single chemical phenomenon, the
action of the voltaic cell.
Analyze your problems. Look for fundamentals. Learn
to connect a law or an event with what went before and what
comes after. Make your education a training in logical
thinking.
This ability to think straight, whether acquired in
Engineering or Arts, is the biggest thing you can.get at
college. Its aid as a means to success applies equally to
whatever work you take up—since mental processes are the
same everywhere. It is the power which enables a mechanic
to become sales manager,a lawyer to head a great industrial
organization. Develop it, if you would be ready when your
big opportunity comes.

I could go on to tell how the

efforts to gain the good opinion of

went to dances on two successive

The last supper on the train was

Adonis was toastmaster and, with

Max Rosen with a glass, egg,

RESERVE BASEBALL TEAM IS
GOING STRONG

(THE BOOK MART)

The Johns Hopkins secondstring baseball teams have had,
to date, a rather successful season. At the first part of the season it was planned to have this
team composed entirely of Freshmen, but because of conditions
which have arisen, such as the
blacklist, lack of candidates and
the number of Freshmen on the
first squad, it was later decided
to form the reserve team instead
of a team composed wholly of
Freshmen.
The first game of the season
was won handily from Mt. St. Joseph's. In the second game City
College trounced the reserves, but
justice was meted out in the third
contest, when City was defeated.
It was necessary to call off the
trip to Mercersburg, which was
scheduled for the Easter recess
because of the heavy schedule
which the Varsity team was undertaking that week calling for
a strong reserve strength and
consequently, the second team
remained at home to fill in any
gaps.
Friends' School will be met at
Homewood next Tuesday, May 3,
at 4:15 P. M.

Tomorrow the Hopkins stickmen will line up against one of
their most formidable opponents
of the season, the Syracuse University twelve. So far this sea
son neither Hopkins nor Syracusc
has been defeated, Hopkins having won four games, and Syracuse
two. Two weeks 'ago Syracuse
opened their season,- by defeating
the Crescent Club of New York.
This, in itself, shows that the
Orange stickmen have real class,
for any club that can beat the
Crescents must show form well
above the average.
Last year the game between
Hopkins and Syracuse resulted in
a 4-4 tie. Darkness stopped the
game before enough extra periods
could be played to finally decide
the contest. Both teams this year
have largely the same lineup as
last, so the undecided game will
be fought out tomorrow.
In the game last Saturday the
Hopkins twelve showed up to a
disadvantage, due largely to overconfidence and to poor condition.
The Syracuse team, by beating
the Crescents, showed real ability
and demonstrated that the Hopkins twelve has no reason whatsoever to be overconfident.

Since the Easter holidays
men
Knipp has been putting the
through some hard scrimmages
track
and has had them doing
their
improve
work in order to
wind. When the team lines up
against the Orange men tomorrow it will undoubtedly be in better shape than at any previous

The ball team will meet Gettysburg College tomorrow at Homewood at 2 o'clock. At the present
zime little is known of the
3trength of the visitors, although
_hey have always been known to
urn out very strong teams.
The Black and Blue team has
:3een rather successful this year,
having broken even in six games,
riot counting, of course, the Ori)le romp. The height of form, so
far, was shown in the Pittsburgh
game, when "Bobby" Owings
pitched Hopkins to a 4-2 victory.
It is expected that "Ben"
Thomas, who sprained his ankle
in a practice game a week ago,
will be in condition to return to
his old position at short for tomorrow's game."Ben," who, until

AS TO CRITICS, WISE OR OTHERWISE
Like all other home products, the News-Letter comes in for its.
share of knocks. We are glad to say, however, that ninety-five per
cent, of the criticism received comes from that class who talk a
great deal and function rarely.
The most common criticism of our sheet has been the objection to the large proportion of advertising matter. Comparison with
our exchanges, however, reveals the fact that there are fewer than
five, among the hundred or more college sheets, which have less
advertising space than our paper. In some instances the ad matter
covers two entire pages, leaving one page for notices and the front
of the sheet for news. The ad is, of course, the heart's blood of the
publication, as the news is the meat. Without the advertiser the
paper could not exist.
We realize that criticism of the work of the editorial staff is at
times justified. But we would like to call to the attention of our
critics the fact that the half-dozen men who spend from eight to
twelve hours per week at work upon the paper are not experts and
are only human; and, furthermore, that anyone of them will retire
in favor of a better man. Remember,"It is easier to be critical than
to be correct."

A REAL OPPORTUNITY
Hopkins, in the\ spring time, has opportunities that many a large
university buried in some small town would pay a large sum to own.
The wonderful athletic facilities at Homewood attract hundreds of
athletes from Baltimore prep. schools. Upon the impression that
these athletes carry back to their institutions depends, to a large
extent, the future of Hopkins.
The City of Baltimore, with its six or eight thousand male
high school students, offers as excellent a field for selection of university material as any college could desire. The director of athletics
at this University has stated that with the material turned out at the
two leading local prep. schools at his disposal, he could develop
'athletic teams to compete with any in the country.
The students who crowd our tennis courts, track and baseball,
and lacrosse fields can learn little from the University officially as to
what we have here to attract students seeking higher education. The
attractive buildings and wonderful athletic facilities speak for themselves, but it remains for the Hopkins man to show these guests that
there is as real a spirit here at Hopkins as exists at any wide-awake
institution.
As our guests, and as prospective students, it is our duty to make
the youngsters feel at home. If we could but develop a keener feeling of friendship between them and ourselves it would not be long
_before this university became the goal of every high school student
in Baltimore.
As it is, we draw a maximum number from this city. Only by
creating a demand for our "goods", however, will we be able to
pick the cream from the number of applicants.

prep. schooler• to Johns Hopkins.

. like as not later on you will turn to

You don't know where opportunity or inclination will
lead you. This fact has a great deal to do with your work
at college—not so much the things you learn as the way
you learn them.
Don't think of education as a memory test in names and
dates and definitions. That knowledge is important, but
only as an incidental. Of far greater value is the habit of
getting at underlying laws,the basic principles which tie facts
together.
The work of the pioneers in electrical experiment, at
first glance confusing, is simplified once you realize that
much of it hinged upon a single chemical phenomenon, the
action of the voltaic cell.
Analyze your problems. Look for fundamentals. Learn
to connect a law or an event with what went before and what
comes after. Make your education a training in logical
thinking.
This ability to think straight, whether acquired in
Engineering or Arts, is the biggest thing you can.get at
college. Its aid as a means to success applies equally to
whatever work you take up—since mental processes are the
same everywhere. It is the power which enables a mechanic
to become sales manager,a lawyer to head a great industrial
organization. Develop it, if you would be ready when your
big opportunity comes.

RESERVE BASEBALL TEAM IS
GOING STRONG

(THE BOOK MART)

The Johns Hopkins secondstring baseball teams have had,
to date, a rather successful season. At the first part of the season it was planned to have this
team composed entirely of Freshmen, but because of conditions
which have arisen, such as the
blacklist, lack of candidates and
the number of Freshmen on the
first squad, it was later decided
to form the reserve team instead
of a team composed wholly of
Freshmen.
The first game of the season
was won handily from Mt. St. Joseph's. In the second game City
College trounced the reserves, but
justice was meted out in the third
contest, when City was defeated.
It was necessary to call off the
trip to Mercersburg, which was
scheduled for the Easter recess
because of the heavy schedule
which the Varsity team was undertaking that week calling for
a strong reserve strength and
consequently, the second team
remained at home to fill in any
gaps.
